What I do

I'm a Ph.D. student of linguistics at UConn.
Previously, I've studied linguistics and computer science in Vienna, Austria.

I work on theoretical and mathematical syntax, and I'm especially interested in Turkic languages and fieldwork on less-familiar languages. Please see below for a list of topics I've worked on.

Download my full CV   (May 2017)

Projects

Please email me for copies of non-linked attachments.

A formal account of Dependent Case Theory
I develop a formal system based on variations of Minimalist Grammars that can capture the observed generalizations.
  • in preparation
German impersonal passives
German has passives that retain accusative case and must receive a generic interpretation. I analyze them as impersonal actives.
  • Manuscript, May 2017.
Turkish differential subject marking
I analyze Turkish DSM based on clause type by analyzing nominalized argument clauses as complex NPs with a silent head noun.
  • TU+2 at Indiana University, Bloomington, IN (poster, cancelled) — Nov 19-20, 2016.
  • ConSOLE 25 in Leipzig, Germany (talk) — Jan 4-6, 2017.
    • Proceedings paper, under revision.
Before/after clauses crosslinguistically (with Marcin Dadan, Kadir Gökgöz, Jayeon Park, Yongsuk Yoo)
  • GLOW 39 in Göttingen, Germany (poster) — Apr 5-7, 2016.
  • FASL 25 at Cornell University, NY (talk) — May 13-15, 2016.
    • Proceedings paper, to appear.
Turkish question particle
  • TU+1 at UMass Amherst (talk) — Nov 21-22, 2015.
    • Proceedings paper, to appear.
The German relative pronoun "welch-" as C0 (with Dalina Kallulli)
  • CGG 24 in Madrid, Spain (talk) — May 28–29, 2014.
  • RALFe at Paris 8 (talk) — Oct 9-10, 2014.
    • Handout
Turkish accusative as topic marker
  • ÖSKL 6 in Vienna, Austria (talk) — Nov 30-Dec 1, 2013.
    • Proceedings paper, in: Wiener Linguistische Gazette 78A, 2014.

Contact

The best way to reach me is by email.
I don't check my Facebook regularly, so please don't message me there.

My preferred pronouns are she/her/hers.

You can write to me in English or German or French. I'll be able to decipher Turkish and BCS as well, but I'll struggle to reply.
